The countries called India have many different opinions. The old name is Shendu, or Xianzhou. Now following the correct pronunciation, it should be called India.
The people of India call it a country according to the place. The customs of different regions are different. The general name is used from afar. Speaking of its beauty, it is called India.
India means moon in Tang.
The moon has many names, this is one of them.

It is said that all sentient beings revolve without stopping, and the long night of ignorance has no one to announce the dawn. It is like the bright sun hiding, and the night lamp continues. Although there is the illumination of starlight, how can it compare to the brightness of the bright moon?
If it is for this reason, then it is compared to the moon.
It is because in that land, sages and worthies succeeded each other in setting an example for the common people, guiding and leading them, like the moon illuminating and overseeing.
For this reason, it is called India.

The various tribes and classes in India, the Brahmins are especially pure and noble. Following their elegant appellation, it has been passed down as a custom. Without mentioning the distinctions of the Buddhist realm, it is generally called the country of Brahmins.
If one speaks of its territory,
the land of the five Indias is over 90,000 li in circumference.
On three sides it borders the great ocean, and in the north it is backed by the Snow Mountains.
In the north it is broad, and in the south it is narrow, shaped like a half-moon. The land is divided into over 70 countries.
The weather is extremely hot, and the land is mostly moist with springs.ğŸ”½In the north, there are hidden hills and mounds, with rugged and barren hills and marshes;
in the east, the fields are fertile, with rich and fertile fields;
in the south, the plants and trees are luxuriant;
in the west, the land is barren and rocky.
This is the general outline, which can be briefly mentioned.
As for the term yojana, it is pronounced as yueshenna in the old [language].
It is also called yujiana and yuyan, all of which are abbreviated forms.
A yojana is the distance an ancient sage king's army could march in one day.
The old transmission says one yojana is forty li;
the customs of India consider it thirty li;
the scriptures only record it as sixteen li.
The smallest unit of measurement is to divide one yojana into eight kroÅ›as.
A kroÅ›a is the distance to which the sound of a large ox's bellow can be heard, called a kroÅ›a.

One kroÅ›a is divided into five hundred bows, one bow is divided into four cubits, one cubit is divided into twenty-four fingers, one finger is divided into seven barley grains, and so on, up to lice, nits, dust motes, ox hair, sheep hair, rabbit hair, gold, and water, each divided seven times, down to the finest dust. The finest dust is divided seven times to form the most minute dust.
The most subtle dust is that which cannot be further divided. When divided, it returns to emptiness, thus it is called the most subtle particle.

As for the movement of the yin and yang calendar, the sequence of the sun and moon, although the names differ, the seasons are no different. Following the stars, the names of the months are designated.
The shortest unit of time is called a ksana.

For laypeople, the day and night are divided into eight periods (four daytime and four nighttime periods), each period having four parts.

When the moon is full, it is called the bright fortnight; when the moon wanes until it disappears, it is called the dark fortnight. The dark fortnight may be either the fourteenth or fifteenth day, because the moon has small and large phases.
The dark fortnight precedes and the bright fortnight follows, making up one month.
Six months make up one ayana.
When the sun travels inside, it moves north;

Those who translated scriptures and vinaya in the past called it sitting in summer or sitting in the waning year. All of these are the customs of the border regions, not understanding the correct pronunciation of China. Sometimes the dialects were not yet integrated, and the translations were erroneous.

As for the towns and villages, the square city is grandly built;
The streets and alleys, the winding paths, the bustling market on the main road, the flag stands lining the road.

Butchers, fishermen, prostitutes, actors, executioners, and those who remove excrement are marked by their dwellings, banished to the outskirts of the city, and their paths come and go, secluded on the left side of the road.

As for the design of their dwellings, the construction of walls and moats, the terrain is low and wet, and the city is mostly built with bricks. As for the various walls and fences, they are either woven with bamboo or wood, with rooms, terraces, and pavilions, flat-roofed board houses, plastered with lime, and covered with bricks.
The various extraordinary structures are designed the same as in China.

Thatched with sedge or grass, or with bricks or boards, the walls are decorated with lime, the ground is smeared with cow dung for cleanliness, and seasonal flowers are scattered around - this is their difference.
The various monasteries are quite extraordinary in design.
With four corner towers rising, three-story heavy pavilions, eaves, railings, beams and pillars, strange shapes and carvings, doors and windows, fences and walls, painted with various colors.
The common people's dwellings are luxurious inside and simple outside.
The inner chambers and main halls are lofty and spacious, with multi-storied terraces and multi-storied pavilions of various styles.
The doors face east, with the throne facing south.
When sitting, they all use rope beds.
The royal family, nobles, commoners, and wealthy people have different decorations, but the rules are the same.
When the king ascends the throne, it is even higher and wider, inlaid with pearls and jades, called a lion throne, covered with fine cotton, and with jeweled footstools.
All the officials, according to their preferences, carve them in different styles, polishing them with rare treasures.
There is no tailoring for clothing and ornaments, valuing plain white, and deemphasizing fancy colors.
For men, it wraps around the waist and armpits, with a horizontal scarf covering the right shoulder. For women, it is a robe with a lapel that hangs down, covering both shoulders.
The top of the head is a small bun, with the rest of the hair hanging down.
Some shave their beards, distinguishing themselves with strange customs.
The head is crowned with a flower garland, and the body is adorned with necklaces.
As for what they wear, it refers to garments made of silk and cotton cloth.
Silk is wild silkworm silk;ğŸ”½hemp cloth is made of hemp;ğŸ”½gauze is woven with fine sheep's wool;
felt is woven with wild animal fur.
Animal fur is fine and soft, and can be spun and woven, so it is considered precious and used for clothing.
In northern India, the climate is bitterly cold, and they wear short and tight clothes, which are somewhat similar to Hu clothing.

The attire of non-Buddhists is varied and strange, some wear peacock feathers, some adorn themselves with skull necklaces, some go naked, some cover their bodies with grass or wooden boards, some pull out their hair or shave their beards, some let their hair and beard grow long, and their clothing is not fixed, sometimes red, sometimes white.
As for the Dharma robes of monks, there are only three robes and a monk's outer robe, and a niá¹£á¹­hÄ«na.
The making of the three robes varies among the schools, with some having wider or narrower edges and some having smaller or larger leaves.
The saá¹ƒkaká¹£ikÄ (covering the armpits) is called yÄmishi in Chinese.
The old name saá¹ƒkaká¹£ikÄ is a mistake. It covers the left shoulder and covers both armpits, with the left side open and the right side closed, and is long enough to reach below the waist.
The nivÄsana (skirt) is called qun in Chinese.

The old name nivÄsana is a mistake. Since it has no belt or suspenders, when wearing it, the robe is gathered into pleats, and a belt is used to tie it. The pleats differ in various schools, and the color is different, either yellow or red.
The ká¹£atriyas and brÄhmaá¹‡as live simply and frugally, with clean and plain clothes.
The king and ministers wear fine and different clothes, with flower garlands and jeweled crowns as head ornaments, and bracelets, necklaces, and other adornments on their bodies.
The wealthy merchants and great traders only wear bracelets.
Most people go barefoot, with few wearing shoes.
Their teeth are stained, either red or black, their hair is cut short, and their ears are pierced. They have aquiline noses and large eyes. This is their appearance.
As for their purity and self-discipline, it is not a pretense of their will.
Whenever they have food, they must first wash their hands. Leftover food is not eaten again, and eating utensils are not passed around.
Earthenware and wooden utensils must be discarded after use.
Gold, silver, copper, and iron are always polished.
After finishing a meal, they chew betel nut to cleanse themselves.
Until they have finished rinsing their mouths, they do not touch each other.
Whenever they urinate or defecate, they must wash with water.
They apply various fragrances to their bodies, namely sandalwood and saffron.
When the king is about to bathe, drums are beaten and stringed instruments are played.
When making sacrifices and bowing to the gods, they bathe and wash their hands.
Examining their written language, it was created by the Brahma Heaven. The original principles and rules consist of forty-seven characters.
They combine objects to form words, and the words are used according to the situation.

The branches and streams flow out, and their source gradually expands. Based on the land and people, there are slight changes. Speaking of the general outline, it is not different from the original source.
However, Central India is particularly detailed and correct. The language is harmonious and elegant, with the same sound as heaven, and the tone is clear and bright, serving as a model for people.
Neighboring countries and different regions practice errors as teachings, competing to pursue vulgar customs, and no one preserves the pure style.
As for recording words and writing events, each has its own office.
The general term for historical records is called NÄ«laprateka (Pure Treasury in Chinese), which comprehensively lists good and evil, and records calamities and auspicious events.
To open the mind and guide progress, the Twelve Chapters are the first guide.
After the age of seven, they gradually learn the Five Great Treatises:
First, ÅšabdavidyÄ (the study of language and linguistics), which explains words, analyzes characters, and distinguishes meanings.
Second, ÅšilpakarmasthÄnavidyÄ (the study of crafts and technology), which includes skills, machinery, yin and yang, and calendrical calculations.
Third, CikitsÄvidyÄ (the study of medicine), which includes spells, exorcising evil spirits, medicine, stones, acupuncture, and moxibustion.
Fourth is the study of logic, which examines and determines what is right and wrong, and investigates truth and falsehood.
Fifth is the study of Buddhism, which thoroughly understands the wonderful principles of the causes and effects of the five vehicles.
The Brahmins study the four Vedas:
Oldly called the Vedas, it is a mistake.
The first is longevity, which refers to nourishing life and cultivating nature.
The second is sacrifice, which refers to making offerings and praying.
The third is peace, which refers to etiquette, divination, military strategy, and battle formations.
The fourth is techniques, which refers to extraordinary abilities, skills, spells, and medical prescriptions.

The teacher must thoroughly study the subtle and profound, and penetrate the mysteries, show the great principles, and guide with subtle words, lift up and skillfully encourage, and encourage the decayed and weak.
If one has a broad understanding and a rebellious mind, then being restrained will open the way to success.
At the age of thirty, with a firm will and accomplished studies, having already attained a position of rank, one first repays the virtue of the teacher.

Those who are fond of ancient learning, who are content to live in seclusion and adhere to moral integrity, who are detached from worldly affairs, who roam freely beyond worldly matters, who are unmoved by honors and insults, whose fame and inquiries extend far, who are highly esteemed by monarchs, none can bend their steps.
However, the country values wisdom, and the customs value lofty understanding. The praise and support are abundant, and the rites and orders are also weighty.
Therefore, they can strengthen their will and study diligently, forgetting fatigue in pursuing arts, seeking the Way and relying on benevolence, not sparing a thousand li.

Although their families are wealthy, their aspirations are equal to those of itinerant travelers. Their provisions for food and clothing are obtained through begging, valuing the Way and not ashamed of lacking wealth.

Those who indulge in pleasure, are lazy in their work, eat extravagantly, and wear expensively, who lack exemplary virtue and are not practicing in a timely manner, will be met with shame and disgrace, and their bad reputation will spread far and wide.

The teachings of the TathÄgata are understood according to one's kind. As the Sage has passed away for a long time, the true Dharma has become diluted. According to one's understanding, all can attain the realization of wisdom through hearing.
The peaks of the various schools' doctrines stood tall, and the waves of their debates were vast. The heterodox schools specialized in their own paths, but all roads lead to the same destination.
There were eighteen schools, each with their own sharp points;
The two vehicles of the Mahayana and Hinayana were distinguished in their abodes.

Those who sat in meditation, walked, stood, and practiced concentration and wisdom were far apart, and the good and bad of the noisy and quiet were greatly different. Following their respective abodes, each had their own rules and regulations.
It was said that the Vinaya, Abhidharma, and Sutra were the Buddha's teachings. Expounding one part would exempt one from being a monastic official;
Two parts would add a private room and supplies;
Three parts would assign an attendant to serve;
Four parts would provide a servant;
Five parts would allow one to ride an elephant carriage;
Six parts would have a guide and a retinue to guard.
When virtue and morality were high, the honors and orders were also different.
When they gathered to lecture and discuss, they examined their strengths and weaknesses, distinguished good and evil, and promoted or demoted the hidden and manifest.

Those who could expound the subtle words and elevate the wondrous principles, with elegant expressions and beautiful rhetoric, and with marvelous eloquence and agility, would then ride on precious elephants, with attendants like a forest.

They would then open up the gates of meaning, blunt the sharp points of words, simplify the principles, and elaborate on the expressions, with the meaning deviating while the words were in accord. They would then smear red and white lead on their faces, cover their bodies with dust, be expelled to the wilderness, and abandoned in ditches and ravines.
Having thus distinguished the virtuous and the wicked, the wise and the foolish were also revealed.
People knew to enjoy the path, and families diligently applied themselves to learning.
Those who left the household life and returned to lay life followed their preferences.

Those who suffered faults and violated the precepts were punished by the monastic community. The light punishment was for the assembly to reprimand them, the next was for the assembly not to speak to them, and the heavy punishment was for the assembly not to live together with them.

Those not allowed to live together were expelled and not considered part of the community. They were driven out of one residence and had nowhere to go. They suffered hardships as wandering guests, and some returned to lay life.
As for those of distinguished clans, there were four streams:
The first is the Brahmins, who are pure in conduct.
They uphold the Way, abide in integrity, and maintain a pure and upright character.
The second is the Kshatriyas, the royal lineage (formerly abbreviated as Kshatriya).
For generations they have ruled with benevolence and forgiveness as their principle.
The third is the Vaishyas (formerly erroneously written as Vaishyas), the merchants.
They trade in goods, moving with the availability of profit, far and near.
The fourth is the Shudras (formerly erroneously written as Shudras), the farmers.
They exert their strength in the fields, diligently working the crops.
These four castes have distinct social strata, with intermarriage and social interactions strictly prohibited between them.
Women are married only once and never remarry.
There are many other mixed castes, with various clans and lineages, each grouping together according to their kind, too numerous to list in detail.
The kings have been from the Kshatriya caste for generations.
But usurpation and regicide have occurred, with members of other castes claiming the throne.
The nation's warriors, all the brave and strong, were selected. Father and son passed down the profession, thus exhausting the art of warfare.
When at home, they lived in walled compounds with guards all around. When on campaign, they would march with troops at the forefront.
There were four kinds of troops in general:
Infantry, cavalry, charioteers, and elephant troops.
Elephants were covered in strong armor, with sharp tusks and hooves. A general would be comfortably mounted, giving orders. Two soldiers on each side would drive them.
Chariots were drawn by four horses. The troop leader would be in the carriage, with soldiers arrayed around, protecting the wheels and flanking the axle.
The cavalry was scattered to pursue and chase the fleeing enemy.
The infantry were light and agile, with the bold and brave selected. They carried large shields and long spears, or wielded swords and sabers, advancing to engage in battle.
All kinds of military equipment were sharp and pointed, such as spears, shields, bows, arrows, swords, sabers, axes, halberds, long pikes, and ropes, which were all practiced in the world.

As for their customs, although their nature is impetuous, their will is very upright and sincere. They do not seek wealth improperly, and in righteousness they yield to others. They fear the sins of the unseen forces and the consequences of life-threatening deeds. Deceit and flattery are not practiced, and oaths are taken as trustworthy. The government emphasizes sincerity, and the customs are still harmonious.

The wicked and rebellious, who sometimes violate the national constitution, plot to endanger the ruler, and their deeds are revealed, are usually confined in prison without being executed. They are left to their own fate and are not considered part of human society.

Those who violate propriety and righteousness, rebel against loyalty and filial piety, have their noses cut off, ears cut off, hands cut off, and feet cut off, or are expelled from the country or sent to desolate lands.

For other offenses, they pay a fine to atone for their crimes.ğŸ”½In trying cases, they do not add punishment based on the words, but ask questions according to the case and impose penalties based on the facts.
If they resist the charges, shame their offenses, and try to cover up their wrongdoing, and if the truth needs to be investigated and the case requires evidence, there are generally four items:
Water, fire, weighing, and poison.
Water means the criminal and a stone are put in a connected bag and sunk in deep water to test their truthfulness;
if the person sinks and the stone floats, then there is a crime, if the person floats and the stone sinks, then there is no concealment.
Fire means burning iron, the criminal sits on it, and is made to step on it, after being made to touch it with the palm, and also to lick it with the tongue;
if false, there is no harm, if true, there is injury.
A weak person cannot bear the heat, holding an unopened flower, scattering it towards the flame;
if false, the flower opens, if true, the flower burns.
Weighing means the person and stone are balanced, the lightness and heaviness are tested;
if false, the person is low and the stone is high, if true, the stone is heavy and the person is light.
Poison means taking a pregnant sheep, cutting open its right thigh, mixing the food portion of the accused with various poisonous drugs in the right thigh;
if true, the poison will activate and kill them, if false, the poison will subside and they will revive.
Setting forth four principles, to prevent the path of a hundred negativities.
The etiquette of paying respect has nine levels:

1. Speaking comforting words, 2. Bowing the head to show respect, 3. Raising the hand in a high bow, 4. Joining palms in a flat salute, 5. Bending the knee, 6. Sitting with legs extended, 7. Kneeling with hands and knees on the ground, 8. Bowing with all five limbs, 9. Prostrating with the whole body touching the ground.
These nine levels are ultimately just one bow.
Kneeling and praising virtue is called utmost respect.
From afar, one bows the head and joins the palms; up close, one kisses the feet and massages the heels.
Whenever conveying words or receiving instructions, one raises the robe and kneels with legs extended.
When receiving bows from those of higher status, there must be comforting words, either patting the head or patting the back, with kind words of guidance to show intimacy.
Ascetic monks, having received respectful bows, only add good wishes, not stopping kneeling and bowing.
According to the matter at hand, there is much circumambulation, either only one round or three circuits, with the number following one's personal wishes.
Whenever encountering illness, they fast for seven days.
Within this period, many recover;
if not yet cured, they then take medicine.
The nature and types of medicine are named differently;
the skills of doctors and the prognostications vary.
At the end, facing the deceased, they wail and cry, tearing clothes, pulling out hair, slapping the forehead, and beating the chest.
Mourning garments are worn without interruption.
The mourning period has no fixed number.
Sending off the deceased and burying them has three procedures:
First, cremation, piling up firewood and burning.
Second, water burial, sinking in the flow and drifting away.
Third, wild burial, abandoning in the forest to feed the beasts.
When the king passes away, they first establish a successor to preside over the mourning and sacrifices, to determine the hierarchy.
In life, they establish virtuous titles; in death, there is no posthumous title.
In a family where there has been a death, no one will accept food;
after the burial, they return to normal without taboo.
Those who send the dead, considering it unclean, all bathe outside the city walls before entering.

When one reaches old age, the time of death is approaching, one is afflicted with chronic illness, and life is feared to be at its end, one becomes disgusted with worldly affairs, wishes to abandon human life, despises birth and death, and hopes to distance oneself from the world.
Then, relatives and close friends play music and hold farewell parties, board boats, beat the drums, cross the Ganges River, drown themselves in midstream, claiming they will be reborn in heaven.
Ten out of ten have not exhausted their vulgar views.
The monastic community has no rule of wailing, when parents die, they chant in remembrance to repay their kindness and pursue the ultimate in filial piety, truly benefiting the deceased.
Since the government is lenient, official duties are also simple, households are not registered, and people have no corvÃ©e duties.
Within the royal fields, they are divided into four parts:
One is to use it to make abundant sacrifices to the ancestors,
second is to bestow it on the ministers who assist in governance and the chief ministers,
third is to reward the wise, the learned, and the highly talented,
fourth is to establish fields of blessings and provide for the various non-Buddhist paths.
Therefore, the taxes are light and the corvÃ©e is frugal, each is at ease with their worldly occupation, and all share the land.
Borrowing the king's fields, they pay one-sixth as tax.
Merchants pursue profit, coming and going, buying and selling, at the ferry crossings and customs barriers, they pay light taxes and pass through.
The state's construction projects do not waste labor, based on their accomplishments, they are paid wages.
For garrison troops, expeditions, palace residences, and camp guards, they recruit according to the situation, offering rewards to those who volunteer.
The chief ministers, the assisting ministers, the minor officials, and the aides each have their own allotted land, and they themselves enjoy their fiefs.
Since the climate and soil are different, the local resources are also varied, with flowers, grasses, fruits, and trees of various kinds and different names.

Namely, mango, amra, madhuka, badara, kapittha, Ämalaka, tinduka, udumbara, mocha, nÄlikera, and panasa fruits. It is difficult to list all of them, so only the rare ones seen in the human world are briefly mentioned.
As for jujube, chestnut, persimmon, and kaki, they are unheard of in India;
Fruits such as pear, apple, peach, apricot, and grapes are planted here and there in the country of Kashmir;
Pomegranate and sweet oranges are planted in all countries.
In terms of farming, plowing, and harvesting, planting is done according to the season, each according to their labor and leisure.
The land produces rice and wheat in abundance.
Vegetables include ginger, mustard, melon, bottle gourd, and huantuo vegetables, etc.;
Although garlic is small, eating it is also rare. If a family eats it, they are driven out of the city.
As for milk, curd, ghee, butter, molasses, sugar, mustard oil, and various cakes and pastries, they are always eaten.
Fish, mutton, rabbit, and deer are occasional delicacies.

Cows, donkeys, elephants, horses, pigs, dogs, foxes, wolves, lions, monkeys, and apes - all these hairy creatures are generally not eaten. Eating them is shameful, despised by the crowd, and they live outside the city, rarely seen in human areas.
As for the differences in wine and liquor, the flavors vary:
Grapes and sugarcane are for the Kshatriyas to drink;
Barley, rice, and distilled liquor are for the Vaishyas and others to drink;
Ascetics and Brahmins drink grape and sugarcane juice, not what is called wine and liquor.
The miscellaneous castes and low classes have no distinction.
However, the utensils they use are different in craftsmanship and quality.
The various necessities are provided without shortage according to the season.
Although cauldrons and pots are used, they do not know how to cook in steamers.
Many vessels are made of unbaked clay, with few using red copper.
Food is served in one vessel, with various flavors harmonized. The fingers are used to measure and distribute, with little use of spoons and chopsticks. Only the elderly and sick use copper spoons.
As for gold, silver, brass, white jade, and fire pearls, they are produced in the local climate and are abundant.
Strange and precious treasures, of various kinds and different names, come from the ends of the seas, and can be easily obtained through trade.
However, their currency usage changes between existence and non-existence, with gold coins, silver coins, cowries, and small pearls.

The borders of the regions of India are fully presented, and the differences in climate are roughly here. The same principles are generally presented in a rough outline, while different governments and customs are described according to the country.
The country of Lamba is over a thousand li in circumference, with the Snow Mountains at its back in the north, and the Black Range on three sides.
The capital city is over ten li in circumference.
For several hundred years, the royal lineage has been extinct. Powerful families compete with each other, without a great ruler. Recently, they have begun to submit to the country of Kapisa.
It is suitable for growing glutinous rice and has plenty of sugarcane. Although there are many forests, there are few fruits.
The climate is gradually warm, with little frost and no snow.
The customs of the country are prosperous and happy. People enjoy singing. They are timid by nature and deceitful in character. They deceive each other and do not consider others first.
Their bodies are small, and their movements are light and restless.
They mostly wear white cotton, and their clothing is colorful.
There are over ten monasteries with few monks, most of whom study Mahayana teachings.
There are dozens of deva temples with many non-Buddhist practitioners.
Going southeast from here for more than 100 li, crossing a great ridge and crossing a great river, I reached the country of NagarahÄra (in the territory of North India).
The country of NagarahÄra is more than 600 li from east to west and 250 li from south to north.
It is surrounded by mountains on four sides, isolated and dangerous.
The capital city is more than 20 li in circumference.
There is no great ruler, and the people are subject to the orders of the king of KÄpiÅ›Ä«.

It is rich in grain, has many flowers and fruits, has a warm and humid climate, and the customs are simple and honest. The people are fierce and brave, and they are light in spending money and fond of learning.
They revere the Buddha's teachings and few believe in other paths.
Although there are many monasteries, there are few monks, and the stupas are dilapidated.
